history.content:
There's the data science major being offered starting next semester, so if that doesn't have a GPA requirement, then that'd be the program with the most CS-type classes in it.

You could go for the Cognitive Science track, which is an interdisciplinary field in CS/Math/Humanities.

You could also do an Applied Mathematics degree and do a machine learning concentration, but if I'm being blunt, if you're not doing well in 61A/70 you might struggle in upper div. math courses as well.

Since you say you're interested in AI/ML, I would say the closest thing for it would be Data Science > Applied Math/Stats > Cog Sci. I would phase 1 Stats C100 (which is data science 100), and other requirements (check out Data 001 Piazza for more details).

Also, being sad about not being able to declare is definitely understandable, but good on you for looking past that and thinking about other alternatives of getting to where you want to be! good luck! :D

children.subject: Did you mean to post some advice? :)

history.content:
I'm a CS-intended transfer student finishing my lower divs right now: 61A, 70, 16A (w/ the exception of 16B). 

I'm doing fairly bad in 61A and 70 right now and I'm not sure I can declare CS. Not sure if my performance is due to declaration stress, adjusting to Berkeley rigor, or simply not understanding the material properly. I have years of successful, non-academic coding experience so I am a little surprised I'm not doing at least average (which I define as B grade on midterms).

It's unfortunate that there's a GPA minimum for doing CS, but that's what we all have to deal with. That said, what other major involves the most CS classes in it? (I'm interested in AI/ML) With said major suggestion in mind, what classes should I enroll in for Spring 2018?

Thanks a lot everyone!
history.subject: Backup plans for not getting into CS
